title: How to Grow Bird's Nest Fern As an Indoor Plant

steps.headline: Water very generously during warmer months and in warm indoor environments.
steps.description: Add water directly to the soil. Test the soil to see how moist it is. Poke your finger into the soil; if it is moist, the plant doesn't yet need watering. If it is dry, it needs watering.

steps.headline: Mist the fronds occasionally to improve humidity.
steps.description: Use a regular spray bottle and mist the leaves directly.

steps.headline: Fertilize regularly.
steps.description: A light feeding plant, keep the dosages of fertilizer low. If the fern is over-fertilized, the fronds can slow down in growth and may become deformed. Avoid fertilizers with urea or high ammonia nitrogen content.

steps.headline: Cut away any dead growth as it appears.
steps.description: This will keep the fern in excellent shape, and ensures that the plant has space to grow healthily.

text: Watering Water very generously during warmer months and in warm indoor environments. Add water directly to the soil. Test the soil to see how moist it is. Poke your finger into the soil; if it is moist, the plant doesn't yet need watering. If it is dry, it needs watering. Mist the fronds occasionally to improve humidity. Use a regular spray bottle and mist the leaves directly. Fertilizing and maintenance Fertilize regularly. A light feeding plant, keep the dosages of fertilizer low. If the fern is over-fertilized, the fronds can slow down in growth and may become deformed. Avoid fertilizers with urea or high ammonia nitrogen content. Cut away any dead growth as it appears. This will keep the fern in excellent shape, and ensures that the plant has space to grow healthily.
